Placeholder
In general, the Search scope should be clear by the context of the component, like the
page and position, and the placeholder should be only “Search”. But, if necessary, the
placeholder can provide a reminder of what is the scope being searched, such as
“Search stores” or “Search support”. Keep the placeholder short and functional, avoid
using it as an instruction or with a promotional tone.

Placement
The Search can be resized and positioned anywhere on the page. Just keep in mind that
once some value is typed in it, it will need to display the 'submit' and ‘clear’ Icons. In that
moment, the width of the Search bar should be enough to accommodate all the
elements inside it.

Scope select
A scope select can be displayed in a Search bar to allow users to refine the Search
scope.
Always prioritise improving the quality of the Search results, when that's not possible,
provide the scope select in cases where the initial search scope is considerably large
and can be subdivided into distinct groups.
When clicking on the scope select, the list of options displayed will have it's style and
behaviour determined by the browser and platform in use. On small devices, avoid
using the scope select, and if necessary offer that functionality in another way, for
example through filters.

Isolated Search experience
On smaller devices it makes sense to isolate the Search experience when autocomplete
suggestions will be displayed while the user types. In this way, the suggestions will have
enough room to be displayed and viewed by the user.
In those cases, make sure that the user always has a back or close button to return to
the previous state. Also make sure that the autocomplete suggestions can be explored
without hiding the Search. This can be done by placing the Search input in a header that
floats above the rest of the content.

Search for Android and iOS
To adhere to the native platform standards in iOS and Android, the Skapa Search
component does not include a Scope select or a Submit button on native mobile, as the
user can press submit on the on-screen keyboard.
Always provide a clear action on the on-screen keyboard when the user searches. The
label/icon on the button for Android and iOS keyboards can be customised.
Use the label “Search” rather than “Enter” or “Done”, as these can be misleading in this
context
